outline.text: REQUEST FOR INFORMATION
RFI 0900
The Idaho Department of Environmental Quality invites you to submit a response to a
Request for Information (RFI 0900) for a Vehicle Inspection and Maintenance
Program including 1) Canyon County and its cities, including Kuna, Idaho and 2)
Canyon County and its cities, including Kuna, Idaho and Ada County and its cities.
Request for Information responses must be received by December 1, 2009.  Please return
your information in a sealed envelope marked “RFI 0900 for Vehicle Inspection and
Maintenance Program” addressed to:  Marcia Todd, Idaho Department of Environmental
Quality, 1410 North Hilton, Boise, Idaho 83706.
The Idaho Department of Environmental Quality wishes to thank your organization for
assisting the State in this endeavor.
Sincerely,
Dave Sande, CPA
Financial Officer

Purpose
The Idaho Department of Environmental Quality (DEQ) is seeking information from
interested vendors regarding methods to efficiently and effectively implement a vehicle
inspection and maintenance (I/M) program in accordance with Idaho Code Section 39-
116B and pending rule Docket number 58-0101-0901, Rules for the Control of Air
Pollution in Idaho.  Please review the information on the following link for specific
information regarding the legal requirements that must be satisfied under the program.
http://www.deq.idaho.gov/rules/air/58_0101_0901_proposed.cfm
DEQ intends to use the information provided to develop a Request for Proposal (RFP) to
implement an I/M program.
Overview
The Legislature enacted, and the Governor signed into law on April 1, 2008, Idaho Code
Section 39-116B, entitled Vehicle inspection and maintenance program.  It requires DEQ
to enter into rulemaking to establish the minimum requirements for a vehicle inspection
and maintenance program when ambient air quality concentrations in an airshed within a
metropolitan statistical area are at or above 85% of a National Ambient Air Quality
Standard (NAAQS) and motor vehicle emissions constitute one of the top two
contributing sources to the concentrations.
Based on recorded air quality monitoring data, DEQ determined that the ozone ambient
concentrations in the Treasure Valley had for the past 3 years, a design value greater than
85% of the ozone NAAQS.  DEQ also determined (included in this determination are
Ada and Canyon counties and the respective cities only) that motor vehicle emissions
constitute one of the top two emission sources contributing to the 85% design value. As a
result DEQ entered into a negotiated rulemaking, and the Board of Environmental
Quality adopted as pending, the rule Docket referenced above.
Per Idaho Code Section 39-116B(3), the affected counties and cities were given the
option of (1) entering into a joint exercise of powers agreement with DEQ, (2) submitting
an alternative motor vehicle emission control strategy that would result in emission
reductions equivalent  to that of an I/M program, or (3) if the affected counties and cities
do not choose (1) or meet the requirements of (2)  then DEQ or its designee must
implement an I/M program for the area.
DEQ received various responses from the cities and counties covering all three options.
Unfortunately, although the proposed alternative motor vehicle strategies submitted by
several entities were commendable, they fell far short of the emission reductions
predicted to result from an I/M program. Consequently, DEQ is seeking information
under this request for information (RFI) to assist in developing a request for proposal
(RFP) to implement the I/M program.
Page 5 of 6
Currently, Ada County and its cities, excluding Kuna, implement an I/M program
pursuant to a joint exercise of powers agreement.  This program was established as part
of a carbon monoxide attainment plan.  It is anticipated that the RFP will seek a cost
proposal to implement a program in Canyon County and the city of Kuna, and a second
cost proposal to implement a program in Ada County.  Interested vendors should
understand that the I/M program being proposed may include: (1) Canyon county and its
cities, and the city of Kuna, or (2) Canyon County and its cities, and the city of Kuna, and
Ada County and its cities. With the information obtained during the RFI and RFP
process, DEQ will discuss with Ada county and its cities the options available.  Ada
County and its cities may enter into a joint exercise of powers agreement with DEQ
wherein they opt to implement the same I/M program as that in Canyon County.  On the
other hand, they may enter into a joint exercise of powers agreement wherein they opt to
continue operating a program similar to that in operation now.
To fulfill the statement of purpose of Idaho Code Section 39-116B, that is to implement
an I/M program in an airshed that is approaching nonattainment, it is DEQ’s goal to
implement as fully as possible an I/M program by the next ozone season, which begins
approximately on June 1, 2010.
Agency Needs
DEQ intends to issue an RFP to identify a successful bidder interested in implementing
an I/M program. At present DEQ is aware of four different types of I/M programs.  These
include a centralized program, where all vehicles are tested at a central location, a
decentralized program, where vehicles are tested in various locations throughout the area
(this is the system currently in place in Ada County), a hybrid version (incorporating
elements of both a centralized and decentralized programs), and a remote sensing
program, where vehicles are screened when traveling by a remote sensor. Those vehicles
that do not pass the screen test are then required to undergo additional testing.  This RFI
requests information about these programs and any other potential suitable programs.
The contractor will be paid through the collection of inspection fees from motorists.  The
fee is capped by Idaho Code Section 39-116B at $20 per vehicle.  From the fee collected,
which could be lower than $20, the contractor must pay DEQ monies sufficient for DEQ
to cover its administrative and oversight costs, fund a public outreach program per Idaho
Code Section 39-116B(2)(g) and reimburse the Idaho department of transportation for
costs associated with the registration revocation procedure described in Idaho Code
Section 39-116B(4).
Response Requirements
DEQ is looking for an efficient and cost effective way to fulfill its statutory requirement
to implement an I/M program.  DEQ intends to use the information collected under this
RFI to issue an RFP.

In responding to this RFI, please provide the following:
If any vendor believes their responses contain confidential information, please mark those
pages accordingly.  Cost information and costing models will be used for budgetary or
planning purposes only, and can be marked confidential if necessary.  DEQ is interested
in suggestions and elements necessary to secure the best possible RFP.
Written responses and supporting information must be received by December 1, 2009.
Please send written response and supporting information to:
Marcia Todd
Idaho Department of Environmental Quality
Fiscal Office
1410 North Hilton
Boise, Idaho  83706
DEQ wishes to thank respondents for assistance in this endeavor.
For more information
